message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The future of theoretical evolutionary game theory
Paper Abstract: Evolutionary game theory is a truly interdisciplinary subject that goes well beyond the limits of biology. Mathematical minds get hooked up in simple models for evolution and often gradually move into other parts of evolutionary biology or ecology. Social scientists realize how much they can learn from evolutionary thinking and gradually transfer insight that was originally generated in biology. Computer scientists can use their algorithms to explore a new field where machines not only learn from the environment, but also from each other. The breadth of the field and the focus on a few very popular issues, such as cooperation, comes at a price: several insights are re-discovered in different fields under different labels with different heroes and modelling traditions. For example, reciprocity or spatial structure are treated differently. Will we continue to develop things in parallel? Or can we converge to a single set of ideas, a single tradition and eventually a single software repository? Or will these fields continue to cross-fertilize each other, learning from each other and engaging in a constructive exchange between fields? Ultimately, the popularity of evolutionary game theory rests not only on its explanatory power, but also on the intuitive character of its models. This article is part of the theme issue ‘Half a century of evolutionary games: a synthesis of theory, application and future directions’.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Ecology":

## Definition and Overview

Ecology is a branch of biology, and is the study of abundance, biomass, and distribution of organisms in the context of the environment.(no content)The term ecology (German: Ökologie) was coined in 1866 by the German scientist Ernst Haeckel.

## Key Concepts

**Ecosystems and Organisms:**
Ecosystems are dynamically interacting systems of organisms, the communities they make up, and the non-living (abiotic) components of their environment. Ecosystem processes, such as primary production, nutrient cycling, and niche construction, regulate the flux of energy and matter through an environment.

**Ecosystem Services:**
Ecosystems sustain life-supporting functions and provide ecosystem services like biomass production (food, fuel, fiber, and medicine), the regulation of climate, global biogeochemical cycles, water filtration, soil formation, and erosion control.

## Subdisciplines

The main subdisciplines of ecology, population (or community) ecology and ecosystem ecology, differ in their contrasting paradigms. The former focuses on organisms' distribution and abundance, while the latter focuses on materials and energy fluxes.

## Community Ecology

In ecology, a community is a group or association of populations of two or more different species occupying the same geographical area at the same time.

Here are the web search results for "Evolution":

## Biological Evolution

The modern evolutionary synthesis defines evolution as the change over time in genetic variation.(no content)Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive; traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, physiology, and behaviour; different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction; and traits can be passed from generation to generation.(no content)Evolution can occur if there is genetic variation within a population, which comes from mutations in the genome, reshuffling of genes through sexual reproduction and migration between populations (gene flow).

## Other Topics Named "Evolution"

The search results also returned several other topics that share the name "Evolution," including:

- **Convergent Evolution**: Convergent evolution is the independent evolution of similar features in species of different lineages.

- **Human Evolution**: Over their evolutionary history, humans gradually developed traits such as bipedalism, dexterity, and complex language.

- **Stellar Evolution**: Stellar evolution is the process by which a star changes over the course of time.

- **Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution**: The Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution, popularly referred to as the "Evo", is a sports sedan and rally car based on the Lancer that was manufactured by Japanese manufacturer Mitsubishi Motors from 1992 until 2016.

Here's what I found about algorithms:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.

## How Algorithms Work

Starting from an initial state and initial input, the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.

## Historical Background

The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics, with a Sumerian clay tablet found near Baghdad and dated to c. 2500 BC describing the earliest division algorithm.(no content)Around 825 AD, Persian scientist al-Khwārizmī wrote texts on computation, and in the early 12th century, Latin translations appeared, introducing the term that eventually became "algorithm" in English.

## Applications

Most algorithms are intended to be implemented as computer programs, but algorithms are also implemented by other means, such as in biological neural networks, electrical circuits, or mechanical devices.

The search results also show various types of algorithms, including pathfinding algorithms (like A*), sorting algorithms, and cryptographic algorithms, each designed to solve specific classes of problems efficiently.

I've performed a web search for "Cooperation" and found several relevant results. Here's what the search revealed:

## General Definition

Cooperation takes place when a group of organisms works or acts together for a collective benefit to the group as opposed to working in competition for selfish individual benefit. In an evolutionary context, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.

## Cooperation in Nature and Evolution

Cooperation is common in non-human animals, with many organisms other than apes, such as fish, birds, and insects exhibiting cooperative behavior: teaching, helping, and self-sacrifice, and the ability to coordinate to solve problems.

## Cooperation in Human Society

Every human achievement is actually reliant on the cooperation efforts that have been created by others, from the cursory to the truly magnificent.(no content)A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".

## International Organizations

The search also returned information about various international cooperation organizations, including the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), and others that focus on political, economic, and security cooperation between member states.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Evolutionary biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Ecology and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology_and_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Portal:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Journal of Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"European Society for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Society_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology_journals"},{"title":"Glossary of genetics and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_genetics_and_evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Index of evolutionary biology articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_of_evolutionary_biology_articles"}]

## Evolutionary Biology

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

### Key Focus Areas

Evolutionary biology explains diversity between species by analyzing changes in a few individuals within a population over multiple generations, with the purpose of determining how genetic variation develops, how it is inherited, and how evolutionary mechanisms shape a population's genetic composition.(no content)Researchers study the traits of organisms to identify which characteristics enhance or reduce survival and reproduction, and advantageous traits tend to be passed on to offspring, contributing to evolutionary change as those traits become more common.

### Historical Development

The idea of evolution by natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin in 1859, but evolutionary biology, as an academic discipline in its own right, emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s.(no content)The discipline of evolutionary biology emerged through what Julian Huxley called the modern synthesis of understanding, from previously unrelated fields of biological research, such as genetics and ecology, systematics, and paleontology.

### Modern Research

The investigational range of current research has widened to encompass the genetic architecture of adaptation, molecular evolution, and the different forces that contribute to evolution, such as sexual selection, genetic drift, and biogeography.(no content)The newer field of evolutionary developmental biology ("evo-devo") investigates how embryogenesis is controlled, thus yielding a wider synthesis that integrates developmental biology with the fields of study covered by the earlier evolutionary synthesis.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Evolutionary game theory"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolutionarily stable strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Evolutionary economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics"},{"title":"Evolutionary graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_graph_theory"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_theory"}]

## Evolutionary Game Theory

Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology.(no content)It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled.

### Origins and History

It originated in 1973 with John Maynard Smith and George R. Price's formalisation of contests, analysed as strategies, and the mathematical criteria that can be used to predict the results of competing strategies.

### Key Differences from Classical Game Theory

Evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change. This is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.(no content)Maynard Smith realised that an evolutionary version of game theory does not require players to act rationally—only that they have a strategy.

### How It Works

In biology, strategies are genetically inherited traits that control an individual's action, analogous with computer programs. The success of a strategy is determined by how good the strategy is in the presence of competing strategies (including itself), and of the frequency with which those strategies are used.(no content)Rules include replicator dynamics, in other words how the fitter players will spawn more replicas of themselves into the population and how the less fit will be culled, in a replicator equation.

### Applications and Impact

Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has contributed to the understanding of group selection, sexual selection, altruism, parental care, co-evolution, and ecological dynamics.

It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has contributed to the understanding of group selection, sexual selection, altruism, parental care, co-evolution, and ecological dynamics.

Web search results for query: "Spatial structure"

Links: [{"title":"Urban structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_spatial_structure"},{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Spatial organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_organization"},{"title":"Space frame - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame"},{"title":"Stereochemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereochemistry"},{"title":"Quadtree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadtree"},{"title":"Spatial database - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_database"},{"title":"Object-based spatial database - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-based_spatial_database"},{"title":"Chemical structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_structure"},{"title":"Spatiotemporal database - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatiotemporal_database"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of spatial structure across different domains:

## General Definition

Spatial organization can be defined as how something is organized internally as well as externally concerning its surroundings. It can be viewed both on a large or small scale and may also include in its discussion, the factors and conditions that lead to a specific organization pattern.

## Key Areas of Application

**Urban Planning**: Urban spatial structure concerns the arrangement of public and private space in cities and the degree of connectivity and accessibility.

**Ecology**: The environment is spatially structured by various ecological processes, which in combination with the behavioral response of species generally results in: Gradients (trends): steady directional change in numbers over a specific distance · Patches (clumps): a relatively uniform and homogenous area separated by gaps · Noise (random fluctuations): variation not able to be explained by a model.

**Biology**: Spatial organization can be observed when components of an abiotic or biological group are arranged non-randomly in space.

**Chemistry**: A chemical structure of a molecule is a spatial arrangement of its atoms and their chemical bonds.

**Architecture & Engineering**: A space frame or space structure (3D truss) is a rigid, lightweight, truss-like structure constructed from interlocking struts in a geometric pattern.

**Databases**: A spatial database is a general-purpose database (usually a relational database) that has been enhanced to include spatial data that represents objects defined in a geometric space, along with tools for querying and analyzing such data.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Reciprocity"

Links: [{"title":"Reciprocity (social psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(social_psychology)"},{"title":"Reciprocity (electromagnetism) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(electromagnetism)"},{"title":"Reciprocity (cultural anthropology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(cultural_anthropology)"},{"title":"Norm of reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_of_reciprocity"},{"title":"Reciprocity (photography) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(photography)"},{"title":"Eisenstein reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eisenstein_reciprocity"},{"title":"Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concealed_Carry_Reciprocity_Act"},{"title":"Helmholtz reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_reciprocity"},{"title":"Quadratic reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_reciprocity"},{"title":"Artin reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artin_reciprocity"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reciprocity across different contexts:

## Social Psychology and Sociology

In social psychology, reciprocity is a social norm of responding to an action executed by another person with a similar or equivalent action.(no content)As a social construct, reciprocity means that in response to friendly actions, people are generally nicer and more cooperative.(no content)The norm of reciprocity requires that people repay in kind what others have done for them, with the expectation that people will respond to each other by returning benefits for benefits, and with either indifference or hostility to harms.

## Cultural Anthropology

In cultural anthropology, reciprocity refers to the non-market exchange of goods or labour ranging from direct barter (immediate exchange) to forms of gift exchange where a return is eventually expected (delayed exchange) as in the exchange of birthday gifts.

## Photography

In photography, reciprocity is the inverse relationship between the intensity and duration of light that determines the reaction of light-sensitive material.

## Physics and Electromagnetism

In classical electromagnetism, reciprocity refers to a variety of related theorems involving the interchange of time-harmonic electric current densities (sources) and the resulting electromagnetic fields in Maxwell's equations for time-invariant linear media under certain constraints.

## Mathematics

The Artin reciprocity law, which was established by Emil Artin in a series of papers (1924; 1927; 1930), is a general theorem in number theory that forms a central part of global class field theory.
